This is the Scheveningen (unless I've forgotten the name, which is very likely!). It has a reputation as a very sturdy defense, however, I've prepared a very rare gambit against it.

Has white gone mad!! No, in fact, this knight sacrifice, though unclear, is usually regarded as very sound.

A mistake. Black's best response is to simply allow the recapture; white should avoid recapturing as long as possible, generally. This move simply exposes the black king to an onslaught.
Allowing the light squared bishop to defend, but more importantly, blocking white's light squared bishop from moving to c4.
Allowing the light squared bishop to defend, but more importantly, blocking white's light squared bishop from moving to c4.
A blunder. Best is to give away the rook with hxg6 and remove the edge from white's attack. The idea is to prevent material loss after something like Bxb6 Qxb6  Bc4 f6.

And black perishes very simply. 

One of the greatest lessons I've taken out of playing this knight sacrifice, the Perenyi, is to forget about the supposed "piece values" (e.g. knight ~ 3, rook ~5). If you think of each piece's usefulness in terms of the current position, it really helps develop your tactical skills among other things!

Anyway, I hoped you enjoyed the game, and I would really recommend similar lines of the Sicilian for anyone having trouble against it.
